column155: This property is located in the Little Woodhull Creek watershed. His property has frontage along the upper reaches of SnowBird Lake, which is an impoundment on Little Woodhull Creek. His land borders a tributary stream where it enters SnowBird Lake.  Dave's land is primarily damp forest with hemlock, spruce, yellow birch, red maple, and some old black cherry. Dave is interested in tapping sugar maples for home use, but, although I did find a few sugar maple leaves, we did not see any mature sugar maples. Red maples are the dominant maple species. The property is part of the SnowBird Lake Association, which has regulations covering land use and tree management. As such, the Associations discourages harvesting trees larger than 6" diameter, which eliminates logging as a management activity. Dave uses windfalls and trees he has thinned for firewood and does not intend to do any extensive woodlot management. Dave's primary interest in managing his land is for deer hunting. While we did see tracks and droppings, the deer population may be low; we did not see much evidence of overbrowsing, and there is moderate undergrowth of tree saplings and witches hobble. The surrounding land is almost entirely forest. There is a small meadow on his property. A springfed brook meanders through the meadow. Dave wishes to keep beavers away from his land; they regularly attempt to colonize the stream in the meadow and the tributary to SnowBird Lake. Unfortunately, this is excellent beaver habitat, and Dave has a continual challenge on his hand. He mows the meadow and trims the willows bordering the creek, which may reduce the attractiveness to beavers, but it also decreases available forage for deer. I have agreed with Dave to look into approaches, such as food plots, for increasing the potential for deer.

Jim's property is primarily second growth mixed hardwood forest. Typical tree species are sugar and red maple, white ash, and some black cherry. There are older white pines here and there. There is a wooded swamp on the property and a number of vernal pools. Jim is not currently interested in logging; his principal interests are wildlife viewing, recreation, and hunting. He does takes several trees for firewood, and he plans to talk with a forester whom he knows.

column84: Forest restoration.  Forest had been heavily logged by previous owner and current owners would like to help restore the stand.  It’s a tough problem given the deer numbers.

Owner is interested primarily in regeneration of better tree stock, possibly walnut or maple species, to replace the aspen and dying ash that make up the bulk of species on the property. There were fewer than a dozen total oak and black cherry trees in an even-aged 30-40 year old stand of aspen, with about 20 even-height pines mixed throughout. Only one timber grade oak existed, and the owner recognized it's special status and value as a keeper. There was a mixture of same-age red maples and a few sugar maples, and we discussed small syrup hobby operations. There is poor drainage in wet season, poor water availability in dry season, and high deer pressure. The owner does not burn wood, and there is no vehicle access to the small woodlot.  We discussed creating another one or two trails into the center of the woodlot, we discussed the presence of a nice vernal pool and the biodiversity that might be observed there, and the owners seemed especially interested in the idea of clearing a small half-acre area of buckthorn/autumn olive/honeysuckle mix to make room for some protected tree seedlings. We discussed creating a water supply to that area by laying an over-ground black vinyl pipe from the house along a new path. The owner had disappointing results from a previous attempt at regeneration with tube/seedlings, apparently because of drought and deer pressure. I sent the owner links to historical aerial photography from the Cornell archives, and discussed geolocation and mapping of individual trees on the property, as well as the DEC annual tree and shrub sale.

The area that the owner was concerned about was a 10acre pasture that he wanted to re-forest.  Follow up - identification of grasses in the pasture area native/non native Eradication of invasive shrubs Recommendation of long term plan - would need a professional to help with this

column155: I love my woodland because it allows me to enjoy nature and wildlife. I own my woodland primarily for recreation, relaxation, and the natural beauty of the woods.  <<MFO comments>> You have a property that was pretty clear from the usual invasive plants that we see in Northeastern Columbia County. The invasives common up here in the Northeastern part of the county are the Japanese stilt grass, autumn olive, multiflora rose and oriental bittersweet. Most of the time these seeds travel on tires, and peoples’ shoes so it is necessary to be vigilant.  Your first comments to us were that you wished to understand your property better. I have included links to various resources available to you, including those you received as hard copy from Shane, and hope that they are helpful.  For the purposes of discussion, I'd like to segregate your property into the area where we entered the property (lowlands) and the area where you plan to put up the house (higher plateau). The lowlands cover the area of the former logging road and is a slightly lower elevation and the higher land is south of the creek that runs through the property. The land near the logging road was wet with an abundance of ferns, which flourish in damp, rich soil. The rest of the property was wooded, though not too heavily because it had been logged periodically. The loggers seem to have taken care of the land harvesting a variety of trees and leaving  a variety of trees behind. You have hardwoods (oak, maples) and some valuable timber such as black cherry. There are also eastern pine and birches interspersed among these trees. You do not appear to have stands of one particular species.  The first question you had was about ticks. Ticks are, as you know, ubiquitous this year because of the relatively mild winter we had. It is best to protect yourselves. You were wearing wellingtons, which is a good thing. It is best to have a couple of sets of clothing (pants and long sleeved shirt), your hats, gloves, and shoes sprayed with permethrin (Sawyer Products SP657 Premium Permethrin Insect Repellent for Clothing, Gear & Tents, Trigger Spray, sold at Amazon). Allow clothing to dry and wash hands well after use as this is a toxic product. This treatment is good for about 6 washes. Information about ticks and tick- borne diseases https://www.cdc.gov/ticks/tickbornediseases/tickID.html,  https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2021/06/11/well/tick-disease-lyme.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-ticks&variant=show&region=BELOW_MAIN_CONTENT&block=storyline_flex_guide_recirc Please feel free to go to your local government sites as well.  Forest Age and Maturity: Shane and I reviewed your intake form to address any specifics you might want covered. Our assumption was that for many years your land was part of a larger parcel of forested land and had not been used for crop production probably due to the presence of wet areas/wetlands. Our guess that it was probably used for timber production under section 480-a of the Real Property Tax Law when it was part of a larger piece of land.  Most of your property has a combination of hardwoods. There is some infiltration of witch hazel that grows about 6-8 ft tall and spreads out tending to shade out younger plants and not allow robust new growth. These are some of the bushes you might want to cull. Our main concern is that throughout the property, there is very little understory regeneration of trees. It is what folks at Cornell describe as an "even-aged" forest. The trees are maybe 50-60 years old and in some cases may be older. There appeared to be a stone wall which suggests that there may have been a farm for crops or livestock many years ago. However, based on the lack of quick growing trees or invasives this may not be an accurate conclusion. This presumption can be easily confirmed with some searching of the Agricultural Census schedule data that farmers were required to complete in mid-19th century. If you are curious just ask. More reading material: https://smallfarms.cornell.edu/2022/10/anticipating-the-next-forest-ecology-and-management-for-sustaining-forests/  Stewardship Plan: otherwise known as David and Roberta’s to-do list. We think it is helpful to plan out proposed landscape level changes by breaking them out into bite-sized projects.   We would suggest starting with the area of your proposed building site. In the meantime, try to keep your loppers (and electric chainsaw? Chainsaw safety: http://ccecolumbiagreene.org/family-consumer-sciences/family-economics-community-resiliency/emergency-preparedness/chainsaw-safety) handy to remove any unwanted species.  For ease of tractor access, I would probably start on the logging road. It is best to convert this road into your driveway as it has been drivable, and the relative pitch is gradual.  The building site (higher land): This area has some valuable trees. It may be a good idea to get a forester to harvest them and give you some cash or use it as payment for assessing the rest of your property. This may be something you should do sooner rather than later so you can benefit from them. They will probably grade the area as well.  The lower area is populated with ferns. This may be an ideal spot to plant some trees. You can use the USDA soil survey map to determine which trees will do well. Your property's Soil Map from the USDA-NRCS. (https://websoilsurvey.sc.egov.usda.gov/app/WebSoilSurvey.aspx)  You can get an idea about the type of soil in your particular area, if you decide to add trees.  Perspective on Tree Growth should you choose to plant in the lowlands (see caveat under "water control") Willow: You have already planted one in the wet area. They do well in wet areas and are fast growing. Some of the other trees are listed below:  The ferns are invasive and hard to eradicate especially if the land continues to be wet. One would have to use a herbicide. I would suggest some trees be planted in the area where the ferns currently are. Planting a tree forces clearing the ground of ferns and digging a large enough hole to put in a young tree. Some of the trees for wet areas are suggested below. In addition, you can also plant hardwoods that are already present on your property in areas where there is a lack of trees. The aim is to have trees of varying ages so you have a ground story with grasses, (if the sunlight reaches it), a middle story with younger trees and an upper story with mature trees.  Black Walnut: should you ever decide to embark on adding trees, this species could be good for the lower land where the ferns are plentiful because (1) it is nut-bearing, thus positive for wildlife; (2) it grows well in rich alluvial soils; (3) it is allelopathic, keeps invasives at bay (via its juglone chemical), but do not put your vegetable garden near it; (4) it makes beautiful flooring, should you want to take one of them down for Black Walnut flooring for your daughter's house in 30 years.  Silver Maple: Can be planted in a swampish area and is a fast grower. Sycamore: Another fast grower and does not mind wet feet.  Apart from the hardwoods on your property you have black cherry trees. These trees do not mind wet feet either and are monetarily valuable to grow. They would make great furniture/cabinet material if you ever decided to harvest them. Be aware that these trees may suffer from Gummosis -- Black Cherry trees ooze a dark gelatinous substance from their bark, which often happens when they are stressed, for example when there is an extremely dry spell.  All of the above listed trees need full sunlight and should grow well if there is no competition and might reduce the harm being done by ferns. As you get more familiar with trees, you can add sugar maple (a stand of them can provide maple syrup) and burr oak could also prosper in wettish areas.  Mushroom cultivation: You expressed a wish to grow mushrooms and ginseng on your property. The Cornell Cooperative Extension of Columbia/Greene County has classes offered periodically throughout the year. You need a water source and shade, which you have in the area near the stream, for growing shitake. A source of hardwood logs too is required and you should keep that in mind when trees are being demolished for your house. You can find the courses offered on the right-hand side of the web page. https://ccecolumbiagreene.org/. If you get on their email list, they will send you monthly reminders.  Water control: You have a stream that runs through your property. You would like to enlarge it so that you have a stream that runs more or less throughout the year and not only during the early spring. You would need to determine where the source of the water is so that you know if your source of water is clean. If it is, then you can perhaps have a little pond that will provide some resource for the birds.  Invasive parasites and other dead trees:   Emerald Ash Borer... Impossible to mitigate at this stage. If you have ash trees (we did not note any) they tend to die off in this area from the emerald ash borer incursion. Ash can be used for firewood or standing snag as shelter for animals. It is sometimes useful to keep standing dead trees, they are a haven for birds and small mammals and insects and provide a food source.  Invasive Plants: Although you had no invasive plants that we could see, this information will help if you see invasives appear. The entire following video link is excellent.   I find it helpful and somewhat complete from the acknowledged expert in the area of invasives control at Penn State U Ag Extension, Dave Jackson.  Identifying and Controlling Invasive Plants on Forestland If you choose to 'cut to the chase' (again) below are the relevant time points in the video for you:  Japanese Stiltgrass is at 14:00 of the video.  Oriental Bittersweet at 33:38.  Japanese Barberry at 42:13.  Honeysuckle at 43:57 Tree of Heaven at 50:28  Government Assistance--  (a) The NYS Trees for Tribs program—If you want to keep the wet areas from erosion, this program helps. Twenty-five trees given to you, if your application is approved. Need to apply first. https://www.dec.ny.gov/animals/77710.html  If you have questions, you may email them at TreesForTribs@dec.ny.gov or call them at (518) 402-94  DEC Regenerate NY Forestry Cost Share Program. You pay 20% of the total bill. You will need to hire/designate a forester and have a plan. Minimum grant from NYS is $10,000 which means your minimum cost under the program is $2,500 on a bill of $12,500. This is granted as a first come, first serve process and stops when the money runs out. Project can take 3 years; so you can amortize your outlay. They have an approved list of contractors to do the work. https://www.dec.ny.gov/lands/119950.html   There are chainsaw classes held by a forester named Bill Lindoff. The class is called Game of Logging. He can be reached at either of these links. If he cannot help you with the clearing of trees at you house site, you can ask him for a recommendation. If you draw a blank there, you can go to the DEC list and pick someone who lives closest to you. http://www.gameoflogging.com/  This site offers many classes, and it is worth attending these classes to learn about chainsaw safety. https://www.nycamh.org/programs-and-services/game-of-logging.php  There are also chainsaw classes for women taught at the Cornell Cooperative Extension taught by Tracey Testo.  The class for women carries the same name.  (c) The DEC Saratoga Nursery sells trees every year at great prices, typically starting in January. The good stuff goes quickly, so you need to keep your eye out on their site.
